Directions
In a small bowl, whisk together salt, MSG, baking soda, five spice powder, and dark brown sugar until well combined. Set aside.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
In a small skillet, toast bay leaves, cumin seeds, coriander seeds, and white peppercorns over medium heat until fragrant, about 1 minute. Transfer to a spice grinder or mortar and pestle and grind until a rough powder is formed. Add spice blend to salt mixture and whisk to combine. Set aside.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Place one pork chop on a clean cutting board and, using the ridged side of a meat tenderizer or blunt side of a Chinese cleaver, pound pork chops gently to 1/4-inch thickness. Set aside and repeat with remaining pork chops. Season each of the pork chops generously with the spice mixture, place in a large bowl or on a rimmed baking sheet, and cover tightly with plastic wrap. Let pork chops rest in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours or up to 8 hours.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Adjust oven rack to upper-middle position (about 6-inches from broiler element) and preheat broiler. Brush inside of buns with melted butter and arrange on a baking sheet. Broil on the upper-middle rack, cut side up, until bread is lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Set aside.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Set a wire rack inside a rimmed baking sheet and line rack with a double layer of paper towels. Fill a medium or large Dutch oven or wok with 2 inches of vegetable oil and set over medium heat until oil registers 375ºF (190ºC).  Remove pork chops from refrigerator, pat dry with paper towels, and set on a clean baking sheet or plate.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Add one pork chop to hot oil, dropping it from as close to the oil’s surface as possible to minimize splashing. Fry, using tongs or long cooking chopsticks to flip halfway through, until golden brown on all sides, 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer pork chop to prepared wire rack and repeat with remaining pork chops.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Sandwich pork chop between toasted buns and serve immediately.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Special Equipment
Mortar and pestle or spice grinder, meat tenderizer or Chinese cleaver, pastry brush, 9- by 13-inch baking sheet, 4-quart Dutch oven, wire rack, rimmed baking sheet, tongs
Notes
If you can’t find thin-cut pork chops, you can purchase 1-inch thick bone-in pork chops. On a clean work surface, place pork chops between two pieces of plastic wrap, and using a meat mallet or the blunt side of a Chinese cleaver, pound pork chops gently until they are a 1/4-inch thick.
Pineapple buns can be purchased from Chinese bakeries. If you can’t find pineapple buns, you can substitute with Portuguese rolls or  6-inch hoagie rolls.
As Serious Eats contributor Max Falkowitz noted in his
guide to five spice
, the powder refers not to the number of spices in it—but the flavor profile. Typically, the blend includes cinnamon, clove, star anise, fennel, and Sichuan peppercorns. As with all spices, I recommend purchasing the blend from single origin spice companies, as the spices tend to be higher quality. I like the blend from Burlap & Barrel, but you can use your preferred brand.
To toast the rolls in a toaster oven, preheat oven to 350ºF (175ºC). Place rolls, cut side up, on the rack and toast until lightly browned, 5 to 7 minutes.
Make-Ahead and Storage
The pork chop sandwiches are best eaten immediately.
